title: How to Make an Opposite Themed Bingo Game

steps.headline: Create your bingo cards.
steps.description: Position the "FREE" space in the middle of the board under the "N" column.

steps.headline: Think of keywords that are opposites of each other.
steps.description:
You might think of things like directions, colors, sizes, distances, etc. Depending on the child's ages, you can choose on the difficulty of the vocabulary. Up and Down
Cold and Hot
Inside and Outside
High and Low
Light and Dark
Tall and Short
Good and Bad
Big and Small
Forward and Backward

steps.headline: Write the keywords around the cards.
steps.description: It's up to you to use the same keywords on every card or have different cards say other terms. This is useful when lots of terms are built up or allow people to have the opportunity to find different things from others.

steps.headline: Distribute the cards out before the game starts.
steps.description: Make sure that everyone has enough time so that they know what they're looking for beforehand.

steps.headline: Call out the opposite vocabulary word.
steps.description: Have the kids eliminate the term found on their card. For example, you say "Dry" and they would have to find "Wet". If the cards won't be used in the future, you can have them cross them out with a marker. You can always preserve them for future games and use tokens or coins to cover them.

steps.headline: Declare a winner.
steps.description: Once a person's card is completely blacked out first, then a winner can be declared. Depending on the complexity of the keywords, people can complete a standard Bingo row or column (up, down, or diagonal).
